context: However several in vivo and in vitro studies have shown that isoprene is a byproduct of cholesterol biosynthesis. The rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis is catalyzed by 3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG4-CoA) reductase which reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonate and CoA. Production of isoprene (2-methyl-l,3-butadiene) which is a major component of human breath from mevalonate has been demonstrated in rat liver cytosol. In fact earlier studies have shown reduction of breath isoprene level with administration of an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor or high cholesterol diet which can suppress endogenous cholesterol synthesis despite their divergent effects on serum cholesterol level. Together these observations demonstrate the link between cholesterol biosynthesis and isoprene production. Elevation of breath isoprene content in our CKD animals was associated with significant increase in serum cholesterol level. Hypercholesterolemia in this model is, in part, due to the associated proteinuria which is known to increase cholesterol production and serum cholesterol level.
